photo.title: ahu tongariki

photo.description: Un tsunami devastó el Ahu Tongariki en 1960, siendo restaurado recién en 1996, gracias a la colaboración japonesa. Solo a un moai se le volvió a poner su Pukao, pues los demás estaban tan deteriorados que se estimó riesgoso volver a ponerles los tocados o sombreros.
photo.tags: tongariki isladepascua iledepaques rapanui moai ahu tepitootehenua
photo.title: Los 15 moais del "Ahu Tongariki"

photo.description: The 15 restored moai at Ahu Tongariki face the volcano Rana Raraku, the left side of which provided the rock from which moai were quarried. The tsunami of May 1960 hit with enough force to scatter some of the toppled Tongariki moai as far as the wall in the distance. On Google Earth: Ahu Tongariki (15 moai) 27° 7'31.82"S, 109°16'36.25"W
photo.title: 20120626_Rapa Nui_4111 Rano Raraku

photo.description: Me in front of Ahu Tongariki with its 15 restored moai. The site was hit by a tsunami in May 1960, redistributing and further damaging the previously toppled moai. Restoration between 1992 and 1996 by Chilean archaeologist Claudio Cristino cost over US$2 million, paid for by the Japanese Government together with a private Japanese construction company, Tadano. On Google Earth: Ahu Tongariki (15 moai) 27° 7'31.82"S, 109°16'36.25"W
photo.title: 20120626_Rapa Nui_4104 crop Tongariki

photo.description: Ahu Tongariki with its 15 restored moai. In front is an abandoned moai that must have broken while being transported from the quarry to the ahu. This site was hit by a tsunami in May 1960, redistributing and further damaging the previously toppled moai (always pushed over onto their faces so they would not be able to ‘see’ any more). Restoration between 1992 and 1996 by Chilean archaeologist Claudio Cristino cost over US$2 million, paid for by the Japanese Government together with a private Japanese construction company, Tadano. On Google Earth: Ahu Tongariki (15 moai) 27° 7'31.82"S, 109°16'36.25"W
photo.title: 20120626_Rapa Nui_4113 Tongariki

photo.description: This Moai is called the "Traveler Moai" because it went to the World Exposition in Japan a few years ago. In return, the Japanese funded the local museum. Behind are the 15 beautiful Moai of Tongariki.

photo.title: Ahu Tongariki

photo.description: Ahu Tongariki with its 15 restored moai. (Note the tiny tourist on the right.) This site was hit by a tsunami in May 1960, redistributing and further damaging the previously toppled moai. Restoration between 1992 and 1996 by Chilean archaeologist Claudio Cristino cost over US$2 million, paid for by the Japanese Government together with a private Japanese construction company, Tadano. On Google Earth: Ahu Tongariki (15 moai) 27° 7'31.82"S, 109°16'36.25"W
photo.title: 20120626_Rapa Nui_4130 Tongariki

photo.tags: ahu ahutongariki built easterisland manmade manufactured moai places
photo.title: Ahu Tongariki and Poike

photo.description: A stray dog (or kiltro to Chileans) checks out petroglyphs carved into the rocky ground at Papa Tataku Poki (adjacent to the Tongariki site). A face can be seen in the center while to the right the apparent focus of the dog’s attention is a traditional birdman with its human body in a fetal position and the head of a bird. On Google Earth: Ahu Tongariki (15 moai) 27° 7'31.82"S, 109°16'36.25"W
photo.title: 20120626_Rapa Nui_4119 Tongariki

photo.description: Petroglyphs carved into the rocky ground at Papa Tataku Poki (adjacent to the Tongariki site) include a traditional birdman with its human body in a fetal position and the head of a bird. On Google Earth: Ahu Tongariki (15 moai) 27° 7'31.82"S, 109°16'36.25"W
photo.title: 20120626_Rapa Nui_4116 Tongariki

photo.description: Petroglyphs carved into the rocky ground at Papa Tataku Poki (adjacent to the Tongariki site) include a tuna. Photo is upside down to make the tuna right side up. On Google Earth: Ahu Tongariki (15 moai) 27° 7'31.82"S, 109°16'36.25"W
photo.title: 20120626_Rapa Nui_4120 Tongariki

photo.description: This is an image of the sun about to rise at Tongariki (also known as 'the 15'). This moai, atop their ahu (burial mound) are the largest set of standing moai on Rapa Nui. As with all the moai on the island, they had been toppled in inter-tribal conflict and by natural events (tsunamis). In 1960, the moai were thrown up to 500m. inland by a major tsunami and the site effectively destroyed. They, and the ahu on which they stand, were later reassembled using huge cranes and form probably the most significant site on Easter Island now, with the exception of the quarry itself. Needless to say, this site is popular with photographers and sees a greater collection of tripods then anywhere else on the island! The moai second from the right is the largest standing - though there is a larger one still in the quarry and attached to the rock - at just under ten metres tall and weighing approximately 90 tonnes. View On Black
photo.tags: easterisland rapanui tongariki moai sunrise pacific isladepascua
photo.title: Tongariki: sunrise

photo.description:
>The sun rising over the remarkable, rebuilt ahu and moai (platform and statues) at Tongariki on Easter Island.
The statue third from the right is the largest one standing on the island, at just under 10 metres tall and approximately 90 tonnes.

photo.title: Ahu

photo.description: Ahu Tongariki with its 15 restored moai can be seen from the moai quarry on the side of the volcano Rana Raraku. This view is unobstructed today, but when the Polynesians first arrived, Easter Island was extensively covered by two species of now-extinct palm trees. Over time, between the adverse impact of the Pacific rats brought by the colonizers (rats that like to eat palm nuts [seeds]) and the needs of a growing Rapanui population (for cooking, for construction materials, for cleared land for farming, for eventually moving moai), the island was denuded. Tongariki was hit by a tsunami in May 1960, redistributing and further damaging the previously toppled moai. Restoration between 1992 and 1996 by Chilean archaeologist Claudio Cristino cost over US$2 million, paid for by the Japanese Government together with a private Japanese construction company, Tadano. On Google Earth: Ahu Tongariki (15 moai) 27° 7'31.82"S, 109°16'36.25"W Rano Raraku (moai quarry) 27° 7'34.09"S, 109°17'20.57"W
photo.title: 20120626_Rapa Nui_4171 Tongariki
